Question Text: Which of the following is an example of a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model?
Choices:
a. IP
b. Ethernet
c. UDP
d. TCP
LLM Explanation: IP (Internet Protocol) is a network layer (layer 3) protocol in the five-layer TCP/IP model. It is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between hosts across network boundaries. Ethernet (b) is a data link layer (layer 2) protocol, while UDP (c) and TCP (d) are transport layer (layer 4) protocols.
URLs: ['Kurose, J., & Ross, K. (2017). Computer networking: a top-down approach. Pearson.', 'Tanenbaum, A. S., & Wetherall, D. (2011). Computer networks. Pearson.']

Question Text: Which of these is an example of something that works on the application layer (layer 5 of the five-layer TCP/IP model)?
Choices:
a. A router
b. A browser
c. UDP
d. An ethernet cable
LLM Explanation: A browser is an example of an application that operates at the application layer (layer 5) of the five-layer TCP/IP model. Browsers interact with web servers using application layer protocols like HTTP to request and display web pages. Routers (a) work at the network layer to forward packets between networks. UDP (c) is a transport layer protocol. Ethernet cables (d) are physical layer components that transmit bits over wires.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Guide: A Comprehensive, Illustrated Internet Protocols Reference by Charles M. Kozierok']

Question Text: Which layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with cabling and connectors?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The application layer
LLM Explanation: The physical layer of the five layer TCP/IP model deals with the physical aspects of network communication, including cabling, connectors, and other hardware components. It defines the electrical and physical specifications for devices and the transmission medium. The physical layer is responsible for converting data into signals that can be transmitted over the network medium.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols by W. Richard Stevens', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/what-is-the-tcp-ip-model']

Question Text: Which level of the TCP/IP five-layer model does a router operate on?
Choices:
a. The data link layer
b. The transport layer
c. The application layer
d. The network layer
LLM Explanation: A router operates at the network layer of the TCP/IP model. The network layer is responsible for addressing, routing, and delivering packets between different networks. Routers use IP addresses to make decisions about where to forward packets to reach their destination network.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0']

Question Text: On which layer are Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies operating?
Choices:
a. The network layer
b. The transport layer
c. The physical layer
d. The data link layer
LLM Explanation: Ethernet standards and some wireless technologies like Wi-Fi operate at the data link layer of the OSI model. The data link layer is responsible for node-to-node data transfer between two devices on the same LAN or WAN. It provides functional and procedural means to transfer data between network entities and might provide the means to detect and possibly correct errors that may occur in the physical layer.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data_link_layer', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/what-is-a-data-link-layer']

Question Text: Which of these allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of ethernet protocol data?
Choices:
a. A hub
b. A collision domain
c. A cable
d. A switch
LLM Explanation: A switch allows connections from many devices and inspects the contents of Ethernet protocol data. Unlike a hub, which simply broadcasts data to all connected devices, a switch intelligently directs data only to the intended recipient device by examining the Ethernet frame headers. This allows a switch to create separate collision domains for each port, improving network performance. A cable is just a physical medium for data transmission, and a collision domain refers to a network segment where devices compete for bandwidth, which can occur in networks using hubs.
URLs: ['CompTIA Network+ Certification Study Guide, Seventh Edition (Exam N10-007) by Todd Lammle, 2018', 'Cisco Networking Academy: Introduction to Networks v7.0 (ITN), 2020']

Question Text: What does LAN stand for?
Choices:
a. Local area network
b. Little area network
c. Large area network
d. Locally available network
LLM Explanation: LAN stands for Local Area Network. It refers to a computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a home, school, computer laboratory, office building or group of nearby buildings.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_area_network', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-a-lan-local-area-network.html']

Question Text: What's a router?
Choices:
a. A physical layer device that prevents crosstalk
b. A device that knows how to forward data between independent networks.
c. A more advanced version of a switch
d. A physical layer device that allows connections for many computers at once
LLM Explanation: A router is a network device that forwards data packets between computer networks. Routers perform the traffic directing functions on the Internet and within enterprise networks. A router is connected to two or more data lines from different IP networks. When a data packet comes in on one of the lines, the router reads the network address information in the packet header to determine the ultimate destination. Then, using information in its routing table or routing policy, it directs the packet to the next network on its journey.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Router_(computing)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/routers/what-is-a-router.html']

Question Text: Which of these is a server?
Choices:
a. A device operating on the data link layer that connects many devices together and inspects ethernet protocol data
b. A device that forwards data between multiple networks
c. Something receiving data from something providing data
d. Something providing data to something requesting the data
LLM Explanation: A server is a device, computer program or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers, known as clients, over a network. In this case, the server is described as 'something providing data to something requesting the data', which aligns with the definition of a server.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Server_(computing)', 'https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/network-layer/what-is-a-server/']

Question Text: What kind of wiring is in cables that communicate in voltage changes that are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros?
Choices:
a. Fiber
b. Aluminum
c. Gold
d. Copper
LLM Explanation: Copper wiring is used in cables that communicate in voltage changes, which are received by the receiving device as ones and zeros. Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and is commonly used in network cables like Ethernet. The voltage changes in the copper wire are interpreted as binary data (ones and zeros) by the receiving device.
URLs: ['https://www.webopedia.com/definitions/copper-cable/', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/Ethernet']

Question Text: What modulation type is used for computer networks?
Choices:
a. RJ45
b. Simplex communication
c. Line coding
d. Line crimping
LLM Explanation: Line coding is the modulation technique used in computer networks to convert digital data into signals suitable for transmission over a physical medium. It involves representing the digital signal with an analog waveform that can be transmitted over the network cable. The other choices are not types of modulation: RJ45 is a connector type, simplex communication refers to one-way data flow, and line crimping is the process of attaching connectors to a cable.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Line_code']

Question Text: What is the difference between full duplex and half duplex?
Choices:
a. Half duplex occurs when hubs are in use; full duplex occurs when switches are in use.
b. Full duplex allows communications in two directions at the same time; half duplex means that only one side can communicate at a time.
c. Full duplex is a form of simplex communications.
d. Full duplex is slower than half duplex.
LLM Explanation: Full duplex communication allows data to be transmitted in both directions simultaneously, meaning both devices can send and receive data at the same time. In contrast, half duplex communication only allows data transmission in one direction at a time, so while one device is transmitting, the other can only receive, and vice versa. The choice of full duplex or half duplex is not directly related to the use of hubs or switches, and full duplex is generally faster than half duplex as it allows for simultaneous two-way communication.
URLs: ['https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/ethernet/10563-full-half-duplex-csma-cd.html', 'https://www.comptia.org/content/guides/a-guide-to-network-troubleshooting/duplex-mismatch']

Question Text: The ____________ consists of devices and is responsible for sending signals between devices.
Choices:
a. network layer
b. data link layer
c. physical layer
d. modulation
LLM Explanation: The physical layer is responsible for sending signals between devices. It consists of the actual hardware and physical media used to transmit data, such as cables, connectors, and network interface cards. The physical layer defines the electrical, mechanical, and functional specifications for activating, maintaining, and deactivating the physical link between communicating devices.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by James Kurose and Keith Ross', 'CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom']

Question Text: What is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices?
Choices:
a. Power Cable
b. Twisted Pair Cable
c. VGA Cable
d. SATA Cable
LLM Explanation: Twisted pair cable is the most common type of cabling used for connecting computing devices, especially in Ethernet networks. It consists of pairs of insulated copper wires twisted together to reduce electromagnetic interference and crosstalk. Twisted pair cables are widely used due to their low cost, flexibility, and suitability for high-speed data transmission over short to medium distances.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom (Cisco Press, 2019)', 'Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach by James Kurose and Keith Ross (Pearson, 2016)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/switches/what-is-an-ethernet-cable.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are category types of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP).
b. Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP).
c. Shielded Twisted Pair (STP).
d. USB Cable
LLM Explanation: The three main categories of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable are Unshielded Twisted Pair (UTP), Foiled Twisted Pair (FTP), and Shielded Twisted Pair (STP). UTP has no shielding, making it more susceptible to electromagnetic interference but also cheaper and easier to install. FTP has foil shielding around each pair of wires to reduce crosstalk. STP has a metallic braid or foil that encases each pair of wires, providing better protection against EMI and crosstalk compared to UTP and FTP. USB cable is not a type of Twisted Pair Ethernet cable.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1 by Wendell Odom', 'https://www.pearsonitcertification.com/articles/article.aspx?p=2202410', 'https://www.flukenetworks.com/blog/cabling-chronicles/copper-cable-utp-vs-stp-and-everything-between']

Question Text: How many octets are there in a MAC address?
LLM Explanation: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to a network interface controller (NIC) for use as a network address in communications within a network segment. MAC addresses are most often assigned by the manufacturer of a NIC and are stored in its hardware, such as the card's read-only memory or some other firmware mechanism. A MAC address is typically 48 bits (6 bytes) in length and is expressed as 12 hexadecimal digits grouped in pairs (e.g., 00-1A-2B-3C-4D-5E). Therefore, a MAC address consists of 6 octets.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MAC_address', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/dynamic-address-allocation-resolution/13715-160.html']

Question Text: What address is used for Ethernet broadcasts?
LLM Explanation: The Ethernet broadcast address is FF:FF:FF:FF:FF:FF. This is a special MAC address used to send Ethernet frames to all devices on a LAN segment. When a frame is sent to this address, all devices on that LAN segment will receive and process the frame.
URLs: ['CCNA 200-301 Official Cert Guide, Volume 1, Chapter 2: Fundamentals of Ethernet LANs', 'IEEE 802.3 Ethernet Standard']

Question Text: What is a cyclical redundancy check?
Choices:
a. A way for two computers to synchronize their clocks.
b. The actual data being transported by an Ethernet frame.
c. A technique that allows for multiple logical LANs to operate on the same equipment.
d. A mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact.
LLM Explanation: A cyclical redundancy check (CRC) is a mathematical calculation used to ensure that all data arrived intact during transmission. It is an error-detecting code commonly used in digital networks and storage devices to detect accidental changes to raw data. The sending device calculates a CRC value based on the data being sent and appends it to the transmission. The receiving end then performs the same calculation on the received data and compares the calculated CRC value with the one received. If they match, it indicates the data likely arrived intact without errors.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclic_redundancy_check', 'https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/cyclic-redundancy-checking']

Question Text: Which of the following are ways for transmitting data at the Ethernet level? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Multicast
b. Duplex
c. Broadcast
d. Unicast
LLM Explanation: At the Ethernet level, data can be transmitted in three main ways:a. Multicast - sending data to a group of destination addresses simultaneously c. Broadcast - sending data to all nodes on the networkd. Unicast - sending data to a single destination addressDuplex (b) refers to the mode of communication (half-duplex or full-duplex) rather than a method of transmitting data at the Ethernet level.
URLs: ['https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/routing-information-protocol-rip/13788-3.html', 'https://www.practicalnetworking.net/series/packet-traveling/unicast-multicast-broadcast/']

Question Text: Which of the following are parts of an Ethernet frame? (Select all that apply)
Choices:
a. Broadcast
b. Data payload
c. EtherType field
d. Preamble
LLM Explanation: An Ethernet frame consists of several parts, including:b) The data payload, which contains the actual data being transmitted.  c) The EtherType field, a two-octet field that specifies which protocol is encapsulated in the payload.d) The preamble, a 7-octet field used for synchronization.A broadcast is a type of Ethernet transmission sent to all devices, not a part of the frame itself.
URLs: ['https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_frame', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/lan-switching/8021q/17056-741-4.html']
